body.p:
To his Excellency
Thomas. E. Bramlette
Governor of Kentucky
You Petitioner Frances Stewart would respectfully state that she was fined one hundred dollars at the November Term of the City Court of Louisville for renting a house to be kept for bawdy purposes.

Your petitioner did rent a house to Alice Smith who was a woman of evil fame, the house was sublet by petitioner. It was admitted on the trial by the attorney for the city that petitioner was used as a tool for others who were wiser than she was. In fact petitioner was employed to rent the house by a man who wished to evade the law. He succeeded & petitioner was left to satisfy the law that had been violated unwittingly by petitioner. Your petitioner is a colored woman, unable to read, & did not know at the time that the law forbade the renting of houses to women of evil fame. The rent was paid to the owner of the house, & no benefit accrued to petitioners Your petitioner has replevied the fine & cost amounting to $144 00/00 by pledging all of her house hold furniture, which if taken will strip her of every thing she has in the world. She is old & unable to make a living if thus deprived
of her property. She is unable to pay the find without giving up all she has & she prays your Excellency to remit the amount

I defended old Frances Stewart on the above charge, & could have proved that she was put forward to pull the Chestnut out of the fire, that a white man might save his own fingers; the man had been previously fined for the same offense & to avoid a fine he got the poor old negro to rent it. I think old Fannie perfectly innocent of violating the law knowingly. After she was fined she was arrested on a Copias & to keep out of the work house she mortgaged all she had in the world. If she has to pay the fine & cost which amounts to $144 it will take all she has. I think it a case where the Governor should interpose & save the old woman. I hope you will remit it
I did make the admission as stated in the foregoing petitioner, & believe the same to be true
